snippet.textDisplay:
I'm ok with electronic counting. It can be done on a non-internet connected machine and it's feasible to do quality control manually.


Split the ballots into stacks of 100-1000. Then run the count on each stack. After the machine has counted the ballots, roll dice to determine some stacks to count manually and let candidates/parties request to manually count a few stacks that seem suspicious (ex. 85% yellow votes in a blue region). It would still be less work than counting everything by hand.

You just glossed over blockchain saying it's not anonymous and if it is people can't understand what's happening. That's really poor for an argument. People said others can't understand every single technology that has ever come before us. That argument doesn't work.

snippet.textDisplay: Open-source software is great for research and innovation but terrible for security. "Proprietary" is another way of saying There's someone I can complain to/yell at.

snippet.textDisplay:
You do not know what is happening in Brazil. They have been using use voting computers for more than 25 years. Never had a problem. These computers were custom made in the nineties. They are very big boxes with ancient hardware and a huge and heavy battery. It has no ports, no keyboards, no printer, not even a power cord. It has a touch screen (very low resolution, 64 levels of gray). The software is in machine code. How big is a code to count votes? The code is in an EPROM chip and very short. Any programmer can read it in 2 minutes. That's the way the software is checked.
The computer has a single button linked to a long line. The button opens the vote to be done. The screen has no scrolling or paging. Voter can only touch his vote. It has no confirm or anything else.
The computers are transported to a central to tally the votes. Transportation is inconvenient but somehow you have national presidency results in 3 hours for 90 million votes some in very remote areas.
The only problem they have is the age of the machines. The hardware has been out of production more than 20 years ago, so no new machines can be made. But they still have more then 6000 functioning machines.
Now explain to me how hackers get into a computer which has no ports, is not possible to connect it to the Internet, has no keyboard and you need to change a Eprom that is welded to the motherboard and the code can be read in 2 minutes.

snippet.textDisplay:
If we allow a receipt, this issue of verifying trust is easily solved via modern cryptography. Is the 'anonymity' criteria valuable enough to keep around? Or is it over-valued and net-costing us democracy? 1) political powers already use money to buy influence of voters via ads/fakenews/propaganda, so the argument that 'receipts open the doors to buying votes' seems null because that's already happening without receipts. 2) people choose to be vocal about politics on social media are already identifiable and there are cases of discrimination based on political affiliation. Is the possibility of proving who you voted for really going to make this worse than it already is? 3) You can always choose to destroy your receipt if you don't need it anymore, after you've been satisfied with the integrity of the voting process.

Basically, perhaps we are valuing this anonymity too much, at the cost of keeping the voting system stuck either on inconvenient in-person paper voting, or insecure electronic voting. If losing anonymity doesn't cost us much because the penalties are already in effect anyways, then we gain a lot of benefits from an electronic, cryptographically secure system.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is really no way to prove perjury, but in the United States when there is a contested election, many States, in which there is a recount in which the margin of victory is < 1%, a judge/magistrate with jurisdiction over the election challenge can order the voter (if they have been determined to have a domicile outside of the jurisdiction to state who they voted for under penalty of perjury. I am a former State Assistant District Attorney aka a State Prosecutor who represents the People v. an Alleged Defendant), and I don't know how you can prove the elements for perjury if the voter had moved and the voter registration wasn't properly updated and therefore the election clerk erred in allowing them to vote regularly, as I have never handled any election law cases nor did I take anything over the minimum requirements for administrative law during law school. 

It would be much easier to prove in a situation where the voter's eligibility is in question due to them being able to show proof of a move within the jurisdiction and having a registration card, but once again the bureaucracy went SNAFU on auditing the voter rolls. In such a situation, the voter must use what is called a "Provisional Ballot" which is sealed in an envelope with a signed, sworn affidavit filled out by the voter affixed to the envelope and once the voter's information has been verified and corroborated as valid for that jurisdiction's election, the affidavit for each envelope which has been verified is to be thrown away, the envelopes reshuffled, the ballot taken out, and each provisional ballot becomes a "valid ballot" which is to be "blindly" placed into the ballot box. It would still be a huge challenge to prove that the voter is perjuring themselves if they state they voted for "X Candidate" when they actually voted for "Y Candidate" or "Z Candidate" but they would be placed in the ballot boxes last and their would, at least, be a paper trail with a quasi "Chain of Evidence". These rules vary by State, and depending on the statutory (Legislative Code = Bill passed by the Legislature and signed/affirmed into law by the State's Executive, i.e. Governor) or (Common Law = Appellate Court Rulings on matters of law regarding cases from the past which have a very similar "fact pattern" in which case the Trial Court Judge MUST follow "Stare Decisis" and uphold the decision of the Highest level Appellate Court over their jurisdiction which is known as "Primary, Binding Law".

Such situations apply to; municipality, county, state rep/senate district, statewide election, U.S. federal State House District Representative, U.S. State Senatorial election, or U.S. Presidential elections. It depends on the State Legislature and what State Executive Administrative Regulatory body, often the State's Secretary of State or an Election Commission headed by a Chairperson.

So, by law the voter called as a witness in a contested election in which they were not supposed to vote (they were still on the voter roles, but have moved out of the election's jurisdictional territory for the minimum period of time before their voter registration becomes invalid, or if they were a provisional voter who's ballot was mishandled and "put into the shuffle" before properly being affirmed and corroborated by at least 1-2 other clerks and the Election Judge.

It's a "Gray Area" but a Court can order a voter to divulge the candidate they cast their ballot for in order to settle the election challenge in a tight election where alleged voter fraud/election official ballot tampering has occurred.

In my opinion, the argument "the average person won't understand" is not that important against electronic voting: it makes it harder to attack for layman's, and these complicated systems actually work. You also do your bank work online, don't you?

I believe that an offline system with transfer of encrypted USB drives, and strict security rules (like the way SSL root certificates are protected), should save a lot of time (and money) from all the manual counting, and is a lot harder to do lots of small scale attacks on.

snippet.textDisplay:
I thought this video was much less objective and reasonable than usual. I wish you'd spent more time with a well-informed supporter of electronic voting.

For example, the notion that paper ballots are provably reliable in an easily-understood way doesn't make sense. Is the material technology underlying tamper proof seals somehow more accessible than computer science?

What about the fact that paper ballots are literally plain-text data, trivial to read, alter, or destroy?

Some points you made are indisputable. I wouldn't want voting machines connected to the internet. I wouldn't want voters to have physical access to the voting machines. I wouldn't want closed-source code that had not survived many rounds of pen testing and high bug bounties.

But this video is anything but a balanced consideration of paper vs. electronic voting, and this sort of thinking doesn't delay the day things change, it only reduces our collective preparation for that day.

snippet.textDisplay:
I do think there's benefits to having a hybrid system. You vote on a computer, it prints out a receipt, you confirm the receipt, and the receipt drops into a box. Later, election officials spot-check the receipts to check for attacks.


This would not only make it difficult to run large-scale attacks, but would foil many of the small-scale attacks that paper elections currently face, like "losing" boxes of ballots from a riding that doesn't like your candidate. And when there is and attack, it would make it easier to identify the attack, so you can do an investigation into that riding.


It would also help solve the problem of confusing ballots (I'm looking at you, Florida) because if there's no attack, there's still precedent for large numbers of people voting incorrectly. If there was a printout that you had to verify, then you would see when your vote wasn't as intended.
snippet.textOriginal:
I do think there's benefits to having a hybrid system. You vote on a computer, it prints out a receipt, you confirm the receipt, and the receipt drops into a box. Later, election officials spot-check the receipts to check for attacks.


This would not only make it difficult to run large-scale attacks, but would foil many of the small-scale attacks that paper elections currently face, like "losing" boxes of ballots from a riding that doesn't like your candidate. And when there *is* and attack, it would make it easier to identify the attack, so you can do an investigation into that riding.


It would also help solve the problem of confusing ballots (I'm looking at you, Florida) because if there's *no* attack, there's still precedent for large numbers of people voting incorrectly. If there was a printout that you had to verify, then you would see when your vote wasn't as intended.

snippet.textDisplay:
How to secure vote electronically:
1. Put a certificate in the smartcard of the ID of every resident of the country.
2. Manufacture some cheap open source open hardware devices that can read the smartcard and got a small display and a few buttons. (no other connections)
3. Vote in your browser.
4. Before sending the vote in use the external device in combination with your ID to confirm, hash and electronical sign your vote.
5. Enter the generated hash on the voting Website and send in the result.
6. The result is only valid, if the hash and signature is valid and does match your vote.
7. The main server collects all votes + hashes.
8. After the vote is over, all data is stored on a hard drive. This will be plugged in an “off the net” server that verifies the hashes and counts the votes. This process is done in public.
9. After all the votes got counted and the result is clear, the server will delete all signatures, so the anonymity is ensured.
There are still some problems, but nothing is perfect and you could easily improve on this.
What are your thoughts?

Every system is imperfect and the current antiquated voting systems are insufficient (turnout, fraud, etc.). As with everything, it's a benefit-cost analysis whether to adopt new technologies with its risks and then put resources to force it past the inflection point.

There is no need to put our faulty election system on a pedestal. We trust planes with our lives now and will soon enough be chauffeured around daily by our cars. This use case needs to happen asap.

snippet.textDisplay:
Brazil, a country with close to 150 million voters, uses electronic voting since 1996 and it works just fine. There were never any major issues or security breaches. We know the voting results a few hours after the end of voting. It doesn't meet the anonymity requirements as defined in this video 100%, but it's close enough. Each ballot prints the end result of that ballot, and this information is public. Who votes in each ballot is also public information, so it's not 100% anonymous. But you still don't know the votes of each voter. In my opinion this helps to make the system more trustworthy, because each voter can check if their vote is in that ballot.
Oh, and also, each ballot is physically transported to the central counting place, something you said in the video "no one does".

snippet.textDisplay: 9:56 sorry, but you are wrong about the blockchain and anonymity / trust. The whole point of that tech is that it is transparent, anonymous and tamper-proof. Hashing functions work one way, so you can't get those personal information back, yet it works as a signature that can be used for validation. And trusting comes down to everyone (51+%) agreeing on the state of the network. There arugula problems with proof of work that make this tech not scalable, but there are projects in the works with proof of stake consensus algorithm in place, notably rchain which is inherently concurrent. You are still mostly right about devices, but it is a solvable problem.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the issue is the requirement of anonymity. All of these issues disappear if verification is possible by the voter. If you can go online, check your vote (in a single direction, check not replace). The only necessity of anonymity is to prevent others from knowing how you voted. There's no necessity fundamentally to prevent the voter from being able to identify their vote with a public key system. What's a bad idea isn't electronic voting, it's a truly secret ballet. As long as the mechanism is only possible for the voter, having the ability to verify, and invalidate an incorrect vote by that voter (if somehow it was recorded wrong), would solve every single issue mentioned here. Yes it's not a truly secret ballet, but arguably that doesn't offer significant benefit over a fully secret ballet, while making it very hard to verify that something wasn't tampered with.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm not an expert and I'm sure that someone who is can explain why my idea wouldn't work and I'd love to hear that explanation.
Of course, no system is perfect, but I (again, probably wrongly) believe that my solution offers no more issues than regular ones.

What I think when I talk about internet voting is a website where you have to log in to access to a page where you can submit your vote. In response, you get a unique ID.
Later on, all the votes are shown online alongside the ID which submitted the vote. In this way, everyone can check their own vote and know whether the vote has been changed or not. Also, votes could be counted publicly and there can't be any counting errors or anything of that kind.

The only problems I can think of here are:
1. Identity stealing. If you can access with someone else's name, you can vote on their behalf. This is similar to the problem we have for granny voting. If my identity is stolen and someone votes on my behalf and later on I login and try to vote, the response I should get is "you already voted", alongside an option to void my vote. After that, I can ask whichever institution handles the generation of accounts to change my login informations and basically recover my identity.
2. "Social terrorism", which you explained as the voter entering the booth, plugging in a USB and claiming onlind that it was rigged, making people lose their trust. In this case, the voter could say that they checked their ID and the vote isn't the same as they voted for. I can't think of a way to solve this problem, but I don't think it's a major issue but could become one if large groups claimed that. Maybe voters could be given the possibility to change their vote for a short window after they have been posted, but I think that that's unwanted because people could be subjected to seeing the othrr majorities (although I don't believe that's a bad thing).
3. Internet access. Not everyone has it. The solution just needs installing booths where you can do this if you don't have a PC or internet.

If there's anything I missed, point it out, I'd love to hear it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was listening to the vote counting part. I know our particular US county's machines print the full ballot marked by the individual onto a printed receipt (sealed inside the machine's printer) so they can review their choices. The printers eventualy get sent back, but we read the printed summary from the machine to record votes. They have to double-check the paperwork after election night.

However the voting machine is only an auxiliary to the 99.99% of the county using paper ballots...
